Description.val:
The C/KC-135 is a four engine aircraft used for long range cargo and passenger airlift and to support theater commanders.  The C/KC-135 provides air refueling through either the refueling boom or drogue.  As a cargo aircraft, the C/KC-135 can carry six standard 463-L pallets. There are 400 aircraft (396 KCs, 4 special purpose) in the C/KC-135 inventory. The average age is 55 years, with 22 years of service life remaining. The KC-135 has a retirement strategy through its projected service life of 2040.   

In accordance with Section 1815 of the FY 2008 National Defense Authorization Act (P.L. 110-181), this item is necessary for use by the active and reserve components of the Armed Forces for homeland defense missions, domestic emergency responses, and providing military support to civil authorities.

Funding for this exhibit is contained in PE 0401218F.

Justification.val: Where applicable, justification for individual modifications is provided in the P-3A exhibits.

Description.val:
The Block 45 program replaces legacy parts that are difficult to maintain, driving high sustainment costs, failing at high rates, and are no longer procurable.  The modification includes a new Digital Flight Director (DFD), Digital Radio Altimeter (RA), Digital Autopilot (AP) and Electronic Engine Instrument Displays (EEID). Block 45 requirements are outlined in the Capability Production Document for C/KC-135 Communications, Navigation, and Surveillance / Air Traffic Management (CNS/ATM), dated 17 May 12. Program of record: 400 C/KC-135 aircraft, 19 pilot simulators and 5 cockpit simulators with Block 45.  The Block 45 program's associated Research Development Test and Evaluation funding (PE 0401218F) modified two prototype aircraft. The remaining 398 aircraft will be funded with APAF.  Funding may be used to address Diminishing Manufacturing Sources (DMS) issues.

Milestone/Development Status

Developmental Test & Evaluation completed March 2013.  Milestone C approval received 25 July 2013. Currently in Full Rate Production.

The Rudder Position Indicator (RPI) addresses crew situational awareness for the actual rudder position.  Currently, there are no means to determine actual rudder position within the cockpit.  The program installs a display on each side of the cockpit showing the actual and commanded rudder position and will visually identify differences to the crew.  The RPI program of record is 359 C/KC-135 aircraft and will be funded with APAF. Funding may be used to address Diminishing manufacturing Sources (DMS) issues.

Milestone/Development Status

N/A

This program, P-3A Mod 9827, KC-135 AERO-I SATCOM replacement, is a new start.
Inmarsat's existing third generation satellites (I-3) which provide Aero-I services will no longer be functional after 2023. Aero-I services are used to provide oceanic Controller/Pilot Data Link Communications (CPDLC) to Air Traffic Control and Aircraft Communications Addressing and Reporting System (ACARS) Beyond Line of Sight (BLOS) Command and Control (C2) messages to 618th Tactical Air Control Center (TACC) Global Decision Support System. Program of Record: 359 C/KC-135s and 19 Simulators. Iridium installations planned to be performed by a Contract Field Team. Inmarsat removals planned during aircraft Programmed Depot Maintenance (PDM). This funding request will support potential DMS and obsolescence solutions, to include if optimal, life of type buys or bridge buys limited to the program of record quantity. Funding may be used to address Diminishing Manufacturing Sources (DMS) issues.

Inmarsat equipment removals will occur during PDM starting in FY22 and lasting through FY26.  These costs are enumerated under other government cost (OGC) starting in FY22.

Milestone/Development Status

This program began its RDT&E effort in FY18.

This program, P-3A Mod 9828, Real Time in the Cockpit (RTIC), is a new start.
"Real Time in the  Cockpit (RTIC) is designed to provide real time information to the KC-135 pilot/co-pilot with regards to battlespace, situational and threat awareness.  The RTIC program will provide protected, classified data connectivity via machine-to-machine (M2M) technology enabling the KC-135 to interoperate with global and theater operations, intelligence, and Tactical Data Networks (TDNs) to provide the aircrews the information needed to reduce impacts of enemy and blue-on-blue threats and increase KC-135 combat support effectiveness, mission safety, and enhanced situational awareness (SA). The modification includes displays to the cockpit, ARC-210, SADL & Link-16  Modems, RTIC Airborne Executive Processor (AEP), and the ability to integrate on-board/off-board inputs for threat warning (e.g. RWR, multiple data networks, countermeasures, etc).  The requirement document governing this effort is the Air National Guard/Air Force Reserve Corps (ANG/AFRC) RTIC Capabilities Description Document (COD) Requirements Correlation Table and the Air Mobility Command (AMC) approved KC-135 RTIC Milestone (MS) B Requirements Traceability Matrix (RTM) from the using commands into system performance requirements that can be measured and verified.

This funding ensures the active duty component can flow with the NGB/AFRC NGREA funded production starting in FY19 and going through FY23.  

This program will enter Post Milestone C.

Milestone/Development Status

Program is for Active Duty only.  This will be integrated via NGREA funding and does not require development.
